analyzed: tena kho pana samayena chabbaggiyāḥ bhikkhū jivhā nicchārakam bhuñjanti pe

analyzed: na jivhā nicchārakam bhuñjissāmi iti sikkhā karaṇīyā ati
translated: “‘I will not eat making smacking sounds with my tongue,’ this is how you should train.”
One should not eat making smacking sounds with one’s tongue.

original: Yo anādariyaṁ paṭicca jivhānicchārakaṁ bhuñjati, āpatti dukkaṭassa.🔽Anāpatti—
analyzed: yaḥ anādariyam paṭicca jivhā nicchārakam bhuñjati āpatti dukkaṭassa  anāpatti
translated: If a monk, out of disrespect, eats making smacking sounds with his tongue, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.

There is no offense if it is unintentional, if he is not thinking, if he is sick, if his mouth is dry, if he is speaking, if he is teaching the Teaching, if he is reciting the Teaching, if he is in the midst of a recitation, if he is in the midst of a discussion, if he is in the midst of a recitation of the Monastic Code, if he is in the midst of a legal issue, if he is insane, if he is the first offender.
The ninth training rule is finished.
